content.description:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Phosgene gas (<math alttext="C O C l 2" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>COCl</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math>) can be synthesized in the reaction represented by the following equation.
content.question: A. Complete the Lewis diagram for phosgene in which the formal charge on each atom is zero. Include all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

frqParts.text: A. Complete the Lewis diagram for phosgene in which the formal charge on each atom is zero. Include all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

B. A student claims that the hybridization of the carbon atom is the same in <math alttext="C O" overflow="scroll"><mi>CO</mi></math> and <math alttext="C O C l 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>COCl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer in terms of the hybridization of the <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> atom in each structure.

C. When <math alttext="C O" overflow="scroll"><mi>CO</mi></math> and <math alttext="C l 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are combined, no reaction is observed to occur. The reaction is initiated by exposing the reactants to ultraviolet light that has a frequency of <math alttext="8.67 times 10 to the 14 power inverse seconds" overflow="scroll"><mn>8.67</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>14</mn></msup><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. Calculate the energy of <math alttext="1.00 mole" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></math> of photons at this frequency. Include units with your answer.

skill.text: 3.B: Represent chemical substances or phenomena with appropriate diagrams or models (e.g., electron configuration).
